note.p: Title with epigraph, “The Alps from Schaffhausen”; and title, “Entrance to Schaffhausen” (Poems [1891])—W. G. Collingwood gave the title “The Alps from Schaffhausen” to the poem that begins with the line, “There is a charmed peace that aye”, which is untitled in the MS VIII draft, the sole surviving text. He failed to signal this editorial intervention by surrounding his title with square brackets; instead, confusingly, he preceded this poem with another, which Ruskin did entitle, naming its draft in MS VIII (again, the sole surviving text) “Schaffhausen”, yet which Collingwood renamed “Entrance to Schaffhausen”. He did at least, in this instance, indicate his intervention by enclosing the editorial title in square brackets.

Collingwoodʼs rationale is evident in the epigraph he added to [“The Alps from Schaffhausen”], which he took from Ruskinʼs autobiography, Praeterita. As he commented in a note appended to “Schaffhausen” [“Entrance to Schaffhausen”], the poems are “worth comparing” with the autobiographyʼs narrative as “two accounts” composed “at an interval of more than fifty years apart, the one in verse and the other in prose,” describing the familyʼs first sighting of the Alps from Schaffhausen—the later prose version, he added, being distinguished by “a power of recollective imagination resembling that of Turner” (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:283; Poems [8o, 1891], 1:285). In the Library Edition, the quotations in Collingwoodʼs epigraph are dropped into notes (Works, 2:366–67).

Collingwood was probably correct in his assumptions. While Ruskin does not explicitly identify the town of Schaffhausen in either of the poems, the more developed poem of the two, “There is a charmed peace that aye” [“The Alps from Schaffhausen”], given its cry, “The Alps! the Alps!”, probably not only records the same experience as that recollected in the autobiography; it may also have served as a source for the later prose version.

If it is possible to situate either or both of these poems in Ruskinʼs List of Additional Proposed Contents, they likely belonged under one of the three headings, “Schaffhausen”, “The Alps”, and “The fall of the Rhine”. (It is unclear whether the titles in the list represent section headings or individual poems and essays to be included within sections—or both.) It should be noted that the landscape feature to which Ruskin gives the greatest attention in >“There is a charmed peace that aye>” [>“The Alps from Schaffhausen>”] is the Rhine Falls.

“There is a charmed peace, that aye / . . . / Sabbath noon was calm and cloudless” (MS VIII; Works [1903])—These opening eight lines in the draft of “There is a charmed peace that aye” [“The Alps from Schaffhausen”] are omitted in Poems (4o, 1891), 1:140, and Poems (8o, 1891), 1:140; and the lines are restored in Works, 2:366.
